description: Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The MCSA: Windows Server 2012 is designed to be a mid-tier certification for someone who has been working in the field for several years and has had exposure to large and enterprise size deployments of Microsoft Windows and covers topics that are a “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows Server 2012 servers in a corporate or enterprise environment. Server systems often form a critical piece of the day-to-day operations for any business. The MCSA 70-410 Installing and Configuring Windows Server 2012 exam covers topics like how to install Windows server 2012, how to add roles to it so that your server can perform customized functions and other areas that will help the viewer to ensure their computing environment is functional and stable.
name: MCSA Windows Server 2012 - 70-410
subtitle: Installing and Configuring Windows Server 2012

episodes.description: Over 80% of computers run Microsoft Operating systems [reference]. As a result, the Microsoft Certified Solutions Associate is one of the first steps for those seeking to start a technical career. The MCSA: Windows Server 2012 covers topics that are “must know” for anyone responsible for deploying, maintaining and supporting Windows Server 2012 servers in a corporate or enterprise environment. Server systems often form a critical piece of the day-to-day operations for any business. The MCSA covers topics that will help the learner ensure their computing environment is functional and stable.
episodes.title: Overview of Windows Server 2012 R2
episodes.transcript:
WEBVTT

1
00:00:00.000 --> 00:00:08.758
[MUSIC]

2
00:00:08.758 --> 00:00:12.563
The MCSA or Microsoft Certified
Solutions Associate is one of

3
00:00:12.563 --> 00:00:16.210
the more popular
certifications from Microsoft.

4
00:00:16.210 --> 00:00:19.160
It's designed to be
a mid-tier certification.

5
00:00:20.200 --> 00:00:23.530
Greater knowledge than somebody who's
just getting started in IT, but

6
00:00:23.530 --> 00:00:25.450
not expert lever, level knowledge.

7
00:00:25.450 --> 00:00:28.330
This is somebody who's been working
in the field for several years and

8
00:00:28.330 --> 00:00:33.700
has had exposure to large and enterprise
size deployments of Microsoft Windows.

9
00:00:33.700 --> 00:00:37.860
The MCSA for
Windows Server 2012 is probably the most

10
00:00:37.860 --> 00:00:40.900
commonly sought-after
certification with Microsoft.

11
00:00:40.900 --> 00:00:44.190
These are for technicians who are not
going to be just working with desktops,

12
00:00:44.190 --> 00:00:46.450
but deploying Windows servers.

13
00:00:46.450 --> 00:00:50.130
These might be email servers,
file servers, print servers.

14
00:00:50.130 --> 00:00:52.040
They might be authentication servers.

15
00:00:52.040 --> 00:00:55.210
There's all sorts of different types
of servers you might deploy, and

16
00:00:55.210 --> 00:00:58.640
the MCSA for Windows Server 2012
covers the majority of them.

17
00:00:58.640 --> 00:01:01.780
It shows typical deployment scenarios for
a server.

18
00:01:01.780 --> 00:01:05.290
How to deploy the software successfully,
how to secure the software and

19
00:01:05.290 --> 00:01:09.000
ensure things are working nice and
smooth, and how to troubleshoot and

20
00:01:09.000 --> 00:01:11.680
isolate and correct issues when they
aren't running nice and smooth,

21
00:01:11.680 --> 00:01:14.080
and that makes this really valuable.

22
00:01:14.080 --> 00:01:18.570
If you're working in IT and you're sitting
at a help desk right now, or you're doing

23
00:01:18.570 --> 00:01:22.060
field repairs on computers and you're
looking to move to that next step in your

24
00:01:22.060 --> 00:01:26.560
career, the MCSA for Windows Server
2012 is normally that next step, right.

25
00:01:26.560 --> 00:01:30.090
This is what gets you out of the field and
back at the data center.

26
00:01:30.090 --> 00:01:32.470
Gets you into the server room,
working in equipment there.

27
00:01:32.470 --> 00:01:35.360
Which is usually a little more
exciting than supporting a desktop.

28
00:01:35.360 --> 00:01:37.850
Which can,
can over time become a bit monotonous.

29
00:01:37.850 --> 00:01:39.360
I think we've all been there.

30
00:01:39.360 --> 00:01:41.210
So, let's take a look at
this certification and

31
00:01:41.210 --> 00:01:42.720
get a better idea of what it entails.

32
00:01:42.720 --> 00:01:46.226
All right, the MCSA has been around for
quite a while now.

33
00:01:46.226 --> 00:01:49.227
I don't think it's actually
reached ten years yet but it's,

34
00:01:49.227 --> 00:01:51.090
it's a good seven years at least.

35
00:01:51.090 --> 00:01:54.410
And it's designed to be the,
well that mid-tier certification.

36
00:01:54.410 --> 00:01:56.500
The name has changed a little
bit over the years, but

37
00:01:56.500 --> 00:01:59.560
now it's just the Microsoft
Certified Solutions Associate.

38
00:01:59.560 --> 00:02:02.500
And Microsoft actually has
several different ones.

39
00:02:02.500 --> 00:02:05.570
The one we're about to cover is
the one for Windows Server 2012.

40
00:02:05.570 --> 00:02:10.130
If your position within the company is
one that allows you to work on servers,

41
00:02:10.130 --> 00:02:11.900
that's what this is designed for.

42
00:02:11.900 --> 00:02:15.940
If you're still at the desktop level but
you want to move into the server world,

43
00:02:15.940 --> 00:02:18.390
again, this is the place
that you wanna go.

44
00:02:18.390 --> 00:02:21.600
But, if you're looking to
do desktop support, well,

45
00:02:21.600 --> 00:02:23.840
the server technologies,
they can be helpful.

46
00:02:23.840 --> 00:02:26.230
They help you to understand what's
going on on the server side.

47
00:02:26.230 --> 00:02:28.440
But it's not necessarily
the right place for you to start.

48
00:02:28.440 --> 00:02:32.840
You typically want to go to the MCSA for
Windows 8 or MCSA for Windows 7.

49
00:02:32.840 --> 00:02:35.250
Now, if you're just
getting started in IT so

50
00:02:35.250 --> 00:02:40.250
you've got a resume full of other jobs and
you're looking to launch an IT career.

51
00:02:40.250 --> 00:02:44.460
Well again the MCSA for Windows servers
is not really a great starting point.

52
00:02:44.460 --> 00:02:46.120
In order to set up a server,

53
00:02:46.120 --> 00:02:49.590
there's a lot of foundational
knowledge that you need to have.

54
00:02:49.590 --> 00:02:52.750
So if you're just starting out,
I recommend you jump over to

55
00:02:52.750 --> 00:02:56.440
like the CompTIA A+ and
CompTIA Network Plus certifications.

56
00:02:56.440 --> 00:02:59.940
Those are great starting points for
launching an IT career.

57
00:02:59.940 --> 00:03:02.470
If you're just getting started
in technology altogether you

58
00:03:02.470 --> 00:03:07.440
probably wanna go to either
the CompTIA IT Fundamentals or the MTA,

59
00:03:07.440 --> 00:03:09.570
the Microsoft Technology Associate.

60
00:03:09.570 --> 00:03:13.410
That's designed for people that are just
getting their feet wet in the IT world.

61
00:03:13.410 --> 00:03:15.270
You'll learn about basic
operating systems.

62
00:03:15.270 --> 00:03:18.740
Now, that's foundational knowledge
that you're expected to already

63
00:03:18.740 --> 00:03:21.050
have by the time you get
to the server level.

64
00:03:21.050 --> 00:03:22.400
So if you don't possess it,

65
00:03:22.400 --> 00:03:25.360
there's things that we'll cover in there
that might be a little over your head.

66
00:03:25.360 --> 00:03:26.940
That if you've missed
the foundational knowledge,

67
00:03:26.940 --> 00:03:28.600
you won't be able to build on top of it.

68
00:03:28.600 --> 00:03:31.120
So, definitely check out those
other certifications if you

69
00:03:31.120 --> 00:03:32.560
haven't done those yet.

70
00:03:32.560 --> 00:03:33.770
But, if you're ready for

71
00:03:33.770 --> 00:03:37.650
Windows Server, then the MCSA
2012 is where you want to go.

72
00:03:37.650 --> 00:03:42.620
Now, the MCSA 2012 is actually
built on three different exams,

73
00:03:42.620 --> 00:03:46.080
and each one kind of divides
the topic up a little bit.

74
00:03:46.080 --> 00:03:48.350
So, here we can see the three
different exams, and

75
00:03:48.350 --> 00:03:51.410
we divide it here on ITPROTV
into three separate shows.

76
00:03:51.410 --> 00:03:53.840
There's the 70-410, 411 and 412 shows.

77
00:03:55.830 --> 00:03:58.940
The first one is installing and
configuring Windows Server 2012.

78
00:03:58.940 --> 00:04:01.010
If this is the first time you've used it,

79
00:04:01.010 --> 00:04:03.140
we'll cover how to install
Windows Server 2012.

80
00:04:03.140 --> 00:04:06.920
How to get it in place, and
how to add roles to it so

81
00:04:06.920 --> 00:04:09.670
your server can actually
perform customized functions.

82
00:04:09.670 --> 00:04:11.540
We'll talk about
the Microsoft Active Directory,

83
00:04:11.540 --> 00:04:14.970
which is a critical technology
throughout your server infrastructure.

84
00:04:14.970 --> 00:04:18.840
We'll talk about other security concepts,
and just some of the neat bells and

85
00:04:18.840 --> 00:04:23.020
whistles that are included
in Windows server.

86
00:04:23.020 --> 00:04:25.680
Then, in 411, we go into
Administering Windows Server 2012.

87
00:04:25.680 --> 00:04:30.440
Once you've brought up these services,
now you need to administer them,

88
00:04:30.440 --> 00:04:31.280
you need to run them.

89
00:04:31.280 --> 00:04:35.100
You need to allow it to scale up
to thousands, tens of thousands,

90
00:04:35.100 --> 00:04:36.680
hundreds of thousands of users.

91
00:04:36.680 --> 00:04:41.000
You need to keep it operational and you
need to do some advanced functionality.

92
00:04:41.000 --> 00:04:44.540
And what, that's what we cover in the
Administering Windows Server 2012 show.

93
00:04:45.780 --> 00:04:48.830
And then the end of it is the 70-412

94
00:04:48.830 --> 00:04:52.930
which is Configuring Advanced
Windows Server 2012 Services.

95
00:04:52.930 --> 00:04:56.890
We actually revisit some of the services
from the first two shows, and

96
00:04:56.890 --> 00:05:00.310
go more in depth,
showing some advanced configurations, and

97
00:05:00.310 --> 00:05:04.550
then we phase in some new technologies
like Active Directory Federated Services

98
00:05:04.550 --> 00:05:08.040
that are extremely complex and
challenging.

99
00:05:08.040 --> 00:05:10.780
Not useful at all for
small and medium businesses.

100
00:05:10.780 --> 00:05:13.990
But for large and
enterprise businesses can revolutionize

101
00:05:13.990 --> 00:05:15.630
the way that you offer
services on the web.

102
00:05:15.630 --> 00:05:19.740
So, definitely stuff that you want
to be aware of, and get exposed to.

103
00:05:19.740 --> 00:05:25.580
Now these exams are designed to be taken
in order, so you should start with 70 410.

104
00:05:25.580 --> 00:05:28.420
And then go on to 411 and
then wrap it up with 412.

105
00:05:28.420 --> 00:05:31.170
If you take them out of order,

106
00:05:31.170 --> 00:05:35.270
each exam assumes you already have
the knowledge from the prior exams.

107
00:05:35.270 --> 00:05:37.490
So for example if you start out on 412,

108
00:05:37.490 --> 00:05:40.680
it assumes you already
have a passing knowledge.

109
00:05:40.680 --> 00:05:43.720
Like you passed the exam,
not just in passing.

110
00:05:43.720 --> 00:05:46.540
Of 410 and 411.
If you don't do that, you'll,

111
00:05:46.540 --> 00:05:49.340
you'll get over your head pretty quick and
then you get frustrated and

112
00:05:49.340 --> 00:05:51.470
it's hard to be successful
when you're frustrated.

113
00:05:51.470 --> 00:05:54.470
So you do wanna pursue those in order.

114
00:05:54.470 --> 00:05:59.220
Now for me, I always recommend that
people go ahead and do all three.

115
00:05:59.220 --> 00:06:01.310
Just watch all three in order.

116
00:06:01.310 --> 00:06:04.030
Even before taking that 410 exam.

117
00:06:04.030 --> 00:06:08.890
And the reason I say that is, each one
builds on the one from before it so

118
00:06:08.890 --> 00:06:10.200
there's some overlap.

119
00:06:10.200 --> 00:06:13.560
And that means you're seeing the same
technologies multiple times and

120
00:06:13.560 --> 00:06:15.030
you learn more about it.

121
00:06:15.030 --> 00:06:18.860
If you were to watch all three of
these shows, 410, 411, and 412,

122
00:06:18.860 --> 00:06:23.690
you'll be much more likely to pass that
410 exam the first time you go in there

123
00:06:23.690 --> 00:06:25.990
cuz you've seen the technology so
many times.

124
00:06:25.990 --> 00:06:26.620
All right?

125
00:06:26.620 --> 00:06:29.120
So how you choose to watch
them is ultimately up to you,

126
00:06:29.120 --> 00:06:32.360
but at a minimum,
you do want to watch them in order.

127
00:06:32.360 --> 00:06:35.550
Start with 410, and
then move through each.

128
00:06:35.550 --> 00:06:38.800
When you're ready to take the exam,
the exams are administered through

129
00:06:38.800 --> 00:06:42.540
Pearson VUE, so
you'll just jump over to their website.

130
00:06:42.540 --> 00:06:45.930
You can go straight to it at
www.pearsonvue.com/Microsoft.

131
00:06:45.930 --> 00:06:48.770
That'll take you to Microsoft's page.

132
00:06:48.770 --> 00:06:53.957
And remember VUE is spelled V U E and
so it's pearsonvue.com/microsoft.

133
00:06:53.957 --> 00:06:59.200
The exams are $150 a piece and
you gotta take three of them so

134
00:06:59.200 --> 00:07:02.510
unfortunately there is a little bit
of a shock to the wallet on this one.

135
00:07:02.510 --> 00:07:07.500
Assuming you pass on the first time it'll
be about $450 to take the three exams.

136
00:07:07.500 --> 00:07:11.420
Once you pass,
you get your MCSA Window's Server 2012.

137
00:07:11.420 --> 00:07:17.830
Now the MCSA Windows Server 2012 is also
the first step in obtaining the MCSE.

138
00:07:17.830 --> 00:07:21.120
So once you've completed this
certification the next step is that

139
00:07:21.120 --> 00:07:22.840
MCSE that you hear a lot
of people talk about.

140
00:07:22.840 --> 00:07:26.310
Right, that's the, the certification
Microsoft has that's the most famous.

141
00:07:26.310 --> 00:07:28.720
Everybody's heard of the MCSE.

142
00:07:28.720 --> 00:07:30.500
And that's a lot of people's goal.

143
00:07:30.500 --> 00:07:34.490
But, the MCSE is not designed for
somebody getting started.

144
00:07:34.490 --> 00:07:38.140
It's for somebody who's already
got a wealth of experience.

145
00:07:38.140 --> 00:07:40.430
Already has their MCSA, and

146
00:07:40.430 --> 00:07:45.450
is moving into that larger
consultant type design environment.

147
00:07:45.450 --> 00:07:49.380
And that's a lot different than the person
who's doing the day to day work.

148
00:07:49.380 --> 00:07:51.710
The MCSA is for the doer.

149
00:07:51.710 --> 00:07:52.810
The person who's in the field.

150
00:07:52.810 --> 00:07:54.600
The grunt who's actually
making things happen.

151
00:07:54.600 --> 00:07:56.750
Right?
You're the one bringing up servers and

152
00:07:56.750 --> 00:07:57.310
troubleshooting.

153
00:07:57.310 --> 00:07:58.160
Replacing hard drives.

154
00:07:58.160 --> 00:08:00.260
You're the one who's
actually making things work.

155
00:08:00.260 --> 00:08:04.220
So in a lot of ways, the knowledge we
cover in the MCSA certification is more

156
00:08:04.220 --> 00:08:09.140
valuable than what we learn in the MCSE
and the MCSA is a lot more entertaining in

157
00:08:09.140 --> 00:08:12.770
my opinion because you know, you get
to use a lot of these technologies.

158
00:08:12.770 --> 00:08:14.280
So keep that in mind as you go through and

159
00:08:14.280 --> 00:08:18.570
study that the MCSA is a great place to
start if you're already somebody who has

160
00:08:18.570 --> 00:08:22.110
that experience and you're looking to get
that documented, get it on your resume and

161
00:08:22.110 --> 00:08:26.200
learn all the different things
that Windows Server 2012 can do.

162
00:08:26.200 --> 00:08:29.070
All right, well, if that's what you're
looking for, you're in the right place.

163
00:08:29.070 --> 00:08:31.200
Stay tuned, our episodes are coming up.

164
00:08:31.200 --> 00:08:34.510
If not, keep in mind all the other
certifications that I mentioned.

165
00:08:34.510 --> 00:08:36.590
There's an appropriate one for
you in there somewhere.

166
00:08:36.590 --> 00:08:39.720
You just gotta look to find it and
then pursue your goal.

167
00:08:39.720 --> 00:08:42.890
Regardless of which route you go,
I wish you the best of luck on your exam.

168
00:08:42.890 --> 00:08:44.320
And for those of you sticking with me,

169
00:08:44.320 --> 00:08:46.272
I'll see you in the episodes
here in just a moment.

170
00:08:46.272 --> 00:08:53.079
[SOUND]

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike cover installing Windows Server 2012R2 with a GUI interface. Once installed, they demonstrate how to configure the server using server manager and get the server ready for a production environment.
episodes.title: Installing Server with GUI

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike cover installing Windows Server 2012R2 core. Once installed, they demonstrate how to configure the server using sconfig and get the server ready for a production environment.
episodes.title: Installing Server Core

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Cherokee describe and demonstrate migrating server roles as a preferred method over the use of upgrading and installing the role.  They show us the pre-planning concepts and some of the “Dos” and “Don’ts” when migrating roles.  Cherokee demonstrates the migration of a role from a single server hosting multiple roles to separating the roles by migrating DHCP to a dedicated server.  Cherokee also points out resources that should help in the migration process and shows the features on demand installation of the migration tools.
episodes.title: Migrating Roles

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike demonstrate how add/remove the GUI interface from Server 2012R2. Then they show how to take advantage of Features on Demand.
episodes.title: Features on Demand

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike discuss the important of managing disks and the properties of basic and dynamic disks. They demonstrate the use of Disk Management for configuring disks.
episodes.title: Configuring Disks

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike demonstrate partition management when working with multiple disks. They leverage tools such as DiskPart and the power of PowerShell to configure partitions across multiple disks.
episodes.title: Managing Volumes

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike take a look at virtual hard drives. Again, they use DiskPart to create and manage virtual hard disks. Mike also uses Disk Management to work with VHDs.
episodes.title: Virtual Hard Disks

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike explain the use and importance of using Storage Spaces Mike explains how storage pools and storage spaces mix together to lay the foundation of combining multiple drives into logical storage.
episodes.title: Storage Spaces

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike cover NTFS permissions. They discuss how NTFS permissions are applied, explicit and inherited permissions, blocking inheritance and effective permissions.
episodes.title: Configuring NTFS Permissions

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike cover configuring shares. They discuss and demonstrate the different methods for creating shares. They also talk about offline files, access-based enumeration and Previous Versions.
episodes.title: Configuring Shares

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike conclude their discussion on configuring shares. They talk about the Volume Shadow Copy Service (VSS) and explain its use.
episodes.title: Configuring Shares Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike demonstrate using PowerShell Desired State Configuration (DSC). They use DSC to ensure a Windows role is installed, and a directory is created and populated. They also show how to use parameters with DSC.
episodes.title: Desired State Configuration

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike discuss managing remote servers. They use a Windows 8.1 machine with RSAT installed. They demonstrate configuring the remote servers for remote management.
episodes.title: Using Server Manager

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike discuss managing downlevel servers and servers in non-trusted domains. They demonstrate how to configure them and add them to server manager.
episodes.title: Downlevel & Non-trusted Servers

episodes.description: In this episode, Ronnie and Mike configure 2012r2 server core for remote administration. They use netsh and netdom commands to get the server core ready for remote management.
episodes.title: Configuring Server Core

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike take a look at working with printers at the enterprise level. They take a look at the print management console and its features.
episodes.title: Configuring Printers

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike continue their discussion on printers. They lay out the Easy Print driver and how to set up printer pooling.
episodes.title: Configuring Printers Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike take a look at virtual machine settings. Mike uses Hyper-V Manager to create and configure virtual machines.
episodes.title: Virtual Machine Settings

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike continue their discussion on virtual machine settings.  Mike demonstrates the use of Enhanced Session Mode as well as many other features leveraging the use of virtual machines such as Gen 1 and Gen 2 VMs.
episodes.title: Virtual Machine Settings Part 2

episodes.description:
**Errata - at 01:23 Mike mentions the max size of a .vhd is 2GB. The actual size limit for a .vhd is 2TB**



In this episode Daniel and Mike take a look at creating and configuring virtual machine storage. Mike begins with the creation of VHDs and working with differencing disks and parent disks.
episodes.title: Virtual Hard Drives

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike conclude their discussion of virtual machine storage. Mike talks about how and when to use pass-through disks and managing checkpoints for saving the current state of virtual machines.
episodes.title: Virtual Hard Drives Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike explain the use of virtual networks. Mike begins with an explanation of the different types of virtual switches. He also explains how to set static MAC addresses.
episodes.title: Virtual Networks

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike conclude their discussion on virtual machine networks. Mike talks about how to set VLAN IDs on VMs. He also explains why and when to use legacy versus synthetic network adapters in Hyper-V.
episodes.title: Virtual Networks Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Ronnie and Don explore the weird world of interoperability between IPv4 and IPv6. They demonstrate using ISATAP and Teredo tunnels to allow IPv4 and IPv6 clients to communicate with each other.
episodes.title: Interoperability with IPv6

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike cover DHCP. They discuss installing and configuring DHCP, creating scopes, reservations and options. They also discuss using a relay agent.
episodes.title: Install and Configure DHCP

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike conclude their discussion on DHCP. They wrap up talking about scopes and using reservations versus exclusions. They configure a relay agent and explain when to use one how it fits into a network.
episodes.title: Install and Configure DHCP Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike discuss DNS. They explain the basics of DNS and how both internal and external name  resolution works.
episodes.title: Understanding DNS

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike demonstrate configuring DNS. They configure forwarders, conditional forwarding and root hints. They also discuss managing the DNS cache.
episodes.title: Configuring DNS

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike demonstrate managing DNS. They demonstrate working with the DNS cache, configuring root hints, forwarders, and stub zones.
episodes.title: Managing DNS

topics.title: Deploy and configure core network services

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike get you ready to install Active Directory Domain Services. They cover domain and forest functional levels and ADPrep.
episodes.title: Preparing AD DS Installation

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike discuss the different methods used to install Active Directory. They cover using Server Manager, promoting a core install, and discuss setting up Active Directory on Microsoft Azure.
episodes.title: Installing AD DS

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike continue their discussion about installing Active Directory. They demonstrate how to use the Install from Media option. Then they verify AD installation, including srv record registration and the global catalog.
episodes.title: Installing AD DS Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike discuss creating Active Directory Users.
episodes.title: Creating AD Users

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike discuss the process of automating Active Directory User creation.
episodes.title: Automating AD User Creation

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike discuss the tips and tricks to performing bulk operations when working with the Active Directory.
episodes.title: AD Bulk Operation

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike introduce Active Directory Groups and how they can be used to administer a variety of policies to the correct departments or single users.
episodes.title: Active Directory Groups

episodes.description: In this episode Daniel and Mike conclude their discussion on Active Directory Groups.  They leverage PowerShell for creating groups and demonstrate how the use of policies can be used to restrict the use of certain groups.
episodes.title: Active Directory Groups Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike introduce us to the wonderful world of organizational units. They discuss the various containers and what is allowed and not allowed. They create some OUs and demonstrate their use.
episodes.title: Organizational Units

episodes.description: In this episode Nate and Don examine deploying an Active Directory domain controller inside of the Microsoft Azure cloud data center. They demonstrate securely connecting a local network with a private cloud network using a VPN and then install and promote an Active Directory domain controller.
episodes.title: Microsoft Azure

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike work with ADMX/ADML files and show how to configure a central store, as well as show how to import administrative templates. Then they discuss using starter GPOs.
episodes.title: Create Group Policy Objects

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike work with GPO links. They also demonstrate working with multiple local policies.
episodes.title: Create Group Policy Objects Part 2

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike cover using a GPO to assign User Rights Assignment and Security Options. They also discuss Audit Policy settings within a GPO.
episodes.title: Configure Security Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike discuss and demonstrate application restriction policies. They compare and demonstrate the uses between AppLocker and Software Restriction Policies. They wrap up with explaining situations on when theses rules and policies should be used.
episodes.title: Application Restriction Policies

episodes.description: In this episode, Daniel and Mike talk about the built-in firewall to Windows Server 2012 R2. They show how to configure the firewall to allow and block different types of traffic depending on the needs of the server.
episodes.title: Configure Windows Firewalls
